content.text: Total: \~25 minutes from blank sheet to ready to play.

Every contractor is defined by five stats. These determine what you’re good at, how you fight, and how you survive. Stats range from 2 (below average) to 10 (peak human), with augmentation pushing as high as 15 at severe cost.
Every stat does three things: it generates a Stat Bonus (used for skill checks and combat), it influences a combat role, and it has a passive effect that's always active.
Stat Bonuses are derived from the stat value:
Higher stat = higher bonus. The bonus is added to weapon accuracy rolls in combat and to skill checks that use that stat.
Chrome

Physical strength, toughness, and raw power. • Combat Role: Melee damage and physical dominance. Chrome bonus boosts melee accuracy. High Chrome characters hit harder, carry more, and break things. • Passive Effect: Determines Carry Weight (how much gear, armor, and harvested materials you can haul). Also determines melee weapon access — heavy weapons require minimum Chrome. • Key Skills: Athletics, Harvesting, Intimidation (when physical presence matters).
High Chrome: You’re the one kicking in doors, swinging heavy weapons, and carrying the squad’s harvest. You take hits and keep standing. You’re the reason things die in melee.
Low Chrome: You avoid melee. You carry less. Heavy armor and heavy weapons aren’t options. Stay behind the person with high Chrome.
Reflex

Speed, coordination, and reaction time. • Combat Role: Ranged accuracy and initiative. Reflex bonus boosts ranged weapon accuracy. High Reflex characters shoot first and shoot straight. • Passive Effect: Determines Initiative (who acts first in combat) and movement speed in chase/pursuit situations. • Key Skills: Firearms, Acrobatics, Piloting.
High Reflex: You’re the gunfighter. First to act, hardest to pin down. Ranged combat is your domain. You set the tempo for every fight.
Low Reflex: You’re slower on the draw. Ranged accuracy suffers. You act later in the round, which means reacting to what others do rather than setting the pace.
Grit

Endurance, resilience, and willpower. • Combat Role: Survival. Grit determines Hit Points and resistance to conditions, toxicity, and environmental hazards. • Passive Effect: Determines HP (HP = 12 + (Grit × 2), modified by kit and augments). Also determines toxicity resistance — high Grit contractors can operate in contaminated environments longer. • Key Skills: Medicine, Survival, resisting fear and mental effects.
High Grit: You’re the last one standing. More HP, better toxicity tolerance, harder to put down. The rift hasn’t killed you yet and it’s starting to feel personal.
Low Grit: You’re fragile. Fewer hit points. Toxicity accumulates faster. You need to avoid damage rather than absorb it, because you can’t afford to take hits.
Interface

Mental acuity, technical skill, and magical attunement. • Combat Role: Rift casting (magic). Interface bonus determines rift pattern accuracy and power. High Interface characters are the crew’s spellcasters and technical specialists. • Passive Effect: Determines rift casting ability and hacking/technical proficiency. Also influences how well you interact with dimensional technology, augment systems, and data networks. • Key Skills: Hacking, Rift Lore, Crafting, operating complex equipment.
High Interface: You cast rift patterns that reshape the battlefield. You hack systems. You understand dimensional technology intuitively. You’re the brain.
Low Interface: Magic is unreliable in your hands. Technical work is slow and frustrating. You rely on gear and skill rather than patterns and tech.
Edge

Awareness, charisma, and luck. • Combat Role: Evasion — Edge determines how hard you are to hit. High Edge characters dodge attacks that would flatten others. • Passive Effect: Determines Evasion (base Evasion = 3 + Edge bonus, modified by armor). Also governs social interactions, perception, negotiation, and the ability to read people. • Key Skills: Streetwise, Persuasion, reading situations, spotting danger before it arrives.

High Edge: You’re untouchable in combat and invaluable between missions. You negotiate better prices, gather better intel, read NPCs, and keep the crew out of bad deals. In a world where money is survival, the person who saves the crew 200 credits on a vehicle is worth as much as the person who kills the rift beast.

Low Edge: You’re easier to hit. You miss social cues. The world’s informal economy — the deals, the rumors, the connections — moves around you without stopping. You need someone with high Edge on your crew, or you’re paying retail for everything and walking into ambushes.
Stat Balance
No stat is expendable. Every stat does something essential:

rows: Can't carry gear, can't use heavy weapons, useless in melee
Act last, miss at range, can't escape
Die fast, toxicity kills you, can't take a hit
No rift casting, no hacking, no tech
Easy to hit, bad social outcomes, miss opportunities, pay more for everything

content.text: The base stats are 4 / 4 / 4 / 4 / 4 — average across the board. Your Résumé adjusts these, and Flex Points let you customize further. Most starting characters have one stat at 7-8 (their specialty), two at 4-5 (competent), and one or two at 3-4 (their weakness). Weaknesses matter — they’re what drive you to rely on your crew.
